Expresses intense frustration and denial about his role and destiny, admitting confusion about his own life purpose.
Dismisses the idea of being 'special' or having a grand destiny, focusing instead on pragmatic self-determination.
Gently pushes hair off Parry's face and kisses his forehead, expressing a sincere desire to act for Parry's sake, not out of guilt.
Ventures to climb a building late at night to help Parry despite personal risk and discomfort, showing determination and concern.
Mumbles complaints and insults about the situation and Parry's idealism while climbing, mixing support with cynicism.
Expresses dark humor about his situation and imagines being locked up next to a fellow 'screwball' on a mission from God.
Mentally acknowledges Anne's love and concern through a brief hallucination, whispering her name with quiet emotion.
Climbs over a balcony and continues to climb to the roof despite disorienting sounds and hallucinations, showing persistence and focus.
Mistakes the sound of police sirens and a reporter's presence as real, experiencing a brief lapse in perception and judgment.
Recovers quickly from confusion and resumes his task calmly after realizing the sirens and people were not real.
Tries to overcome fear and cautiously explore a dangerous place to retrieve the Grail.
Responds fearfully but does not show aggression when encountering Edwin Malnick.
Gently opens the glass doors and reverently holds the goblet, smiles at inscription about a child’s hard work.
Discovers Langston Carmichael unconscious with empty vodka and pill bottles; checks his heart and reacts with fear and hesitation.
Slowly backs out of the room uncertainly, indicating hesitation to intervene directly.
Places the 'Grail' in Parry's lifeless hands and sits vigil beside him all night.
Speaks softly to Parry, showing patience and hope for his waking.
Quietly leaves the house after triggering an alarm but checks that no one is around before running away.
Closes his eyes pretending to sleep but listens intently and sheds a tear hearing someone express grief and love for the same woman he was married to.
Smiles and brings a bouquet of flowers to Anne despite her cold and dismissive reception, appearing nervous but sincere.
Listens quietly with eyes closed, pretends to be asleep but is attentive, and shows genuine emotion with a tear rolling down his cheek.
Watches Parry teach patients to sing but does not actively participate or engage with the group.
Approaches Anne holding flowers and smiles, showing an attempt at reconciliation or connection despite feeling nervous.
Appears uncharacteristically nervous and frozen in silence in front of Anne, failing to take confident action.
Confesses his love sincerely despite fear and vulnerability.
Responds passionately and physically to Anne's aggressive reaction with intimacy rather than anger or withdrawal.
Admits his love to Anne despite his nervousness and fear, pushing the words out of him.
Is stunned and physically overwhelmed by Anne's slap, falling to the floor and dropping the flowers.
Responds to Anne's passionate kiss by recovering and engaging back with enthusiasm and confidence.
Seems unsure about his own actions, asking 'Am I doing that?' showing confusion or lack of awareness.
